results.notes:
Found this on a downed tree. Can’t remember what kind of tree.

Edit- *Phlebia acerina seems a good fit for this to me. After some reading on P. acerina and similar species, based on a few key characteristics, I like P. acerina for this.
Defining features:
Macro: Folded hymenium placing it in Meruliaceae. Pale color of the fruit body. Hymenium color (Dried yellowish). Flesh stains yellowish brown in KOH.
Micro: Presence of clamp connections. Spore shape.

References used:

GINNS, J. H. 1975. Merulius: s.s. and s.l., taxonomic disposition and identification of species.
Can. J. Bot. 54: 100-167.

Mycologia, 85(6), 1993, pp. 996-1016.
BIOSYSTEMATIC STUDIES ON PHLEBIA ACERINA,
P. RUFA, AND P. RADIATA IN NORTH AMERICA
KAREN K. NAKASONE AND KENNETH J. SYTSMA

results.notes:
Fongarium : cKc0673
Date : 16.IX.2017
Lieu : Cajo
Biotopes : pousse au sol, dans la mousse, sous conifères;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau 27 mm Ø, convexe puis étalé, glabre, beige à gris chamois, taché de brun rougeâtre pâle au pourtour du centre, sans flocons vélaires, à marge non sillonnée;
Lames libres, serrées, larges, avec lamelles et lamellules, blanches;
Stipe 70 × 5 mm Ø, cylindrique, égal, blanchâtre, dont l’apex est grisonnant et poudreux, terminé par un petit bulbe arrondi;
Voile général laissant un rebord engainant et membraneux blanchâtre à ocre sur le bulbe du stipe;
Voile partiel en anneau supère;
Sous-genre lepidella;

Microscopie sommaire
Basidiospores globuleuses à subglobuleuses 7,4 × 7,5 μm; amyloïdes;

Détermination provisoire par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura aprox 460 msnm, creciendo entre hojarasca; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

Possibly Laccaria ochropurpurea ?

results.notes: Resupinate growth from which develop small, very hairy caps. These 1-2 cm. caps fuse horizontally into long strips. Hairs on caps measure 1 mm. in length. Pores are 1 to 2mm. in size. I can see very slight hints of violet in both the hairs (thumbnail image) and the pores (image # 2060) in certain light conditions. Specimens are fruiting on top and sides of large, very decayed log in mixed woods, primarily oak and hickory. The violet makes me wonder if this might be a species of Trichaptum or perhaps just an artifact due to light conditions.

results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing on a sandy bank of Coopers Rd to the NW of Pakim Pond in the typical oak-pine barrens. The road was recently graded.
The cap is moist, but not viscid, slightly corrugated, and glabrous to touch (like a dog’s nose). The gills are pinkish-cream. The stipe is covered with a fine non-pulverulent whitish coating over what looks like a pale pinkish-tan background color; a slight touch left finger-print impression on the surface. The latex is whitish and scant, non-changing and not staining the gills. Crushed flesh has a non-distinct and faint odor. The flesh tastes acrid slowly.
The aforementioned properties led me to Key C and D in Milk Mushrooms of NA by B-H-B, as I couldn’t decide about the cap color. Working through Key C didn’t result in anything resembling this species. Key D gave L. imperceptus as a possibility.

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura aprox 600 msnm, creciendo sobre tierra; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

results.notes:
A single specimen growing on the raised sandy bank of Coopers Road, ~200 ft to the north of intersection with the Red Trail. Young oaks, oak saplings, and mature pitch pines seen at the collection site, but I believe the bolete is mycorrhizal with the oaks. This is the same spot, give or take a few yards, where obs 245956 was collected. Given the strong morphological semblance adjusted for age, I am almost certain it’s the same species.
Morphological Description: The convex-pulvinate medium brown to yellow-brown cap is 4.5 cm wide and 1.5 cm thick in the middle; the cap margin is wavy and devoid of a sterile tissue overhang; the cap flesh is yellowish-cream, slowly staining faintly blue when exposed to air in the middle of the cap and at the cap-stipe juncture, but not above the tubes.
The pores are mustard-yellow to greenish-yellow, 1-1.5 mm wide, angular, somewhat compound, with some reddish-brown natural stains; the yellowish-green tubes are 1.3-1.5 cm deep and not staining blue.
The stipe is 4.5 cm long, gently tapering downwards to a pointy tip, 1.3 cm wide at the apex and 0.8 cm wide near the base; the stipe surface is yellow in the apex, covered with a coating of reddish-cinnamon scruffy dots/pruina below, ridged in the apex and coarsely reticulated below down to about the middle and more or less smooth below and down toward the base; the stipe flesh is generally concolorous with that of the cap, but with deep yellow areas below the stipe surface and in the base, not staining blue.
The basal mycelim is both white and yellow (see pix).
The spore print is yellowish olive-brown when fresh, pale grayish-olive at low humidity.
Macrochemical Tests: KOH = mahogany/brown on the cap pellicle; amber brown on cap flesh. NH4OH = green flash under the reagent drop and green halo (due to vapors), resolving brown; yellow-brown to olivaceous-brown under the drop with pinkish ring around it and a malachite-green halo on cap flesh(see pic).
Spore Data & Discussion: Mounted in Melzer’s and measured only in the profile (dorsi-ventral) view; [20/1/1], L x W = (10.5-) 11.6~14.6 × 4.2~4.7 (-4.9) μm, L’ x W’ = 12.9 × 4.5 μm; Q = (2.37-) 2.48~3.2 (-3.32), Q’ = 2.87, cylindric to elongate based on the Q values; dingy yellow to greenish-yellow and persistently dextrinoid in the posterior half, the dextrinoid reaction varies from a light pinkish hue to a pronounced medium brownish-red infusion; moderately ventricose and spindle-shaped and sometimes constricted in the anterior end in the area of the suprahilar plage in the face (dorsal/ventral) view; inequilateral, subfusiform to fusiform and somewhat ventricose, with a well-defined suprahilar plage in the profile view.
For their own collections of illudens, Smith & Thiers (The Boletes of MI) report spores of 10-14 × 4-5 μm that are “…bluish gray slowly becoming brownish in Melzer’s (fleeting amyloid), rarely slightly dextrinoid…”. I didn’t notice any fleeting amyloid reaction in 293363 probably because (1) I was not looking for it and/or (2) because by the time I finally looked at the spores at x1000, the reaction could have already run its course. Smith & Thiers’ examination of the spores from Peck’s illudens type is reported as 11-13 × 4-4.5 μm, “in Melzer’s merely slightly tan…”. The dextrinoid property of spores of any intensity is absent in their collections of spacideus/spadiceus var. gracilis, subtomentosus/subtomentosus var. perplexus and tenax. I don’t know what to make of the dextrinoid spores of 293363 in the context of its tentative identification as illudens – based on the macromorphological traits of this collection and matching them to the literature descriptions of this taxon – but other existing collections of this entity, e.g., obs 245956, obs 249274 and obs 249357 should perhaps be examined for repeatability this interesting property.

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura aprox 500 msnm, creciendo sobre tierra; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura aprox 500 msnm, creciendo sobre tierra; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). results.notes:
Growing on waterlogged and mossy hardwood logs in a stream. Specimens deteriorated somewhat in my fridge before being photographed. All structures inamyloid in dried material. Asci unitunicate, operculate and with 8 uniseriate spores. Spores hyaline, smooth and thick-walled. Spore measurements: (21.9) 22.5 – 27.6 (29) × (12.3) 12.7 – 16.3 (19.6) µm, Q = (1.5) 1.53 – 2 (2.2); N = 30, Me = 25 × 14.5 µm; Qe = 1.7

Mirrored on iNaturalist at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/8293460

results.notes:

Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). results.notes:
These do not appear to be immature fruit bodies, just very small, possibly due to the dry weather of the previous several weeks. So, although I obtained spores from mounting gill material, I think the spores are mature. (I wanted to get both of these tiny mushrooms into the dehydrator asap.)

Stipe apex with flakes/granules.
Odor faintly of radish.
Growing on the edge of a field near a row of Scotch pine.

When I first saw the spores, I thought the elongate/subfusiform shapes pointed away from genus Hebeloma. But, I see on Champignons du Quebec a species named H. fusisporum. I think my collection probably does not represent this species… but maybe, something close. The L/W quotient (see below) is significantly different from what is reported for fusisporum.

Spores ~9.5-14 × 4.5-6. 2.1<Q<2.6.

results.notes:
in boggy area with many doug-fir cones
largest ones still quite small
Even the very young “button” like ones were green/brown mottled on top. Greenish yellow gills turning brown quickly with age and exposure. Not bruising blue anywhere. Caps moist, smooth and sort of slimy.
Did not have an odor. Unfortunately they were too fragile to take, even the young ones. Generally, the younger ones seemed to have a bit more of the olive green tones on the cap, but there was overlap. Stipe heavily reticulated in the upper half and no obvious annulus.
Even when younger the stipes were never white, eliminating brevipes. None of the caps appeared to be fibrillose or scaly, though they became wrinkled. I can eliminate lakei, pungens, placidus, umbonatus, and tomentosus as well. It seems highly unlikely to be fuscotomentosus, pseudobrevipes, viscidus, the granulatus group and anomalus additionally. There were about a dozen altogether, so if this were glandulosipes I think I would have noticed hanging veil chunks on at least one. Some similarities to punctatipes, but that species seems too fibrillose on the cap. I am confident it is not caerulescens which is also usually paler. Riparius would match the habitat very well and could fit the pores and colors. However, the colors and characters of the stipe seem a little off for that species. There are a few obscure species for which it is very hard to find recent information.
Megaporinus should have larger pores and different stipe

results.notes:
white base stained amber yellow when rubbed
Cap colors range from blackish purple and reddish purple to chestnut brown
Pale, whitish flesh unstaining with exposure
Growing in the middle of a rotted out Douglas fir, possibly growing out of it, but haps through it from the ground just underneath, as the log was heavily rotted. Also many pines in the area
Pores and underside very weakly and slowly staining greenish blue
Cap never ended up cracking really apart from the initial splitting. Trauma areas on pileus ended up with small rosy-purple outer ring. With age the dark purple and reddish tones disappeared with the pileus becoming a relatively dark chestnut brown
Underside of cap and basal mycelium white. Cap about 11 cm wide. Spores medium brown,
perhaps just slightly olivaceus.

As far as species are considered, salicola can easily be eliminated by habitat, and amylosporus by spore color and other features. Zelleri has a pale ring on the pileus rim, and other features make that unlikely. Dryophilus eliminated by habitat and visible characters.

results.notes:
FINAL GROWTH UPDATE/HARVEST 12/8/17:
After exactly two months of photographing/monitoring this sporophore’s growth on a nearly week to week basis, it was time to harvest what I could of it. Many areas where mold(Trichoderma spp.) had covered the fruiting body in early November(dry spell and record heat) had to be left and I simply cut away freshly groing and healthy tissue. Heavy freezing fog in the last 3 days was causing these sections that had Trichoderma on them in early growth stages to become soggy and wilted by harvest time. What a fun and interesting opportunity this year(and many years to come) to monitor this beautiful species in such close proximity to our new home here in Olympia, WA. I plan to continue an annual monitoring and harvest with each following season of this species- granted another mycophile doesn’t discover it and pull up the rhizomatous/rooting stem ;). It’s amazing to me that the steady growth of this collection continued even with an infestation of mold, record temps/weather and overall odd weather patterns for the season. A truly resilient and antibiotic rich creature.

GROWTH UPDATE ON 11/25/17. Nearly or at full maturity. The section closest to the substrate(Douglas fir) where I cut a small sample for dehydration a week ago is beginning to discolor to light brown and is waterlogged. Almost the entire remaining sporophore material is extended and lobes are frilled and fully expanded. Compare with original images taken on 10/8/17 when the overall fruiting body was compact and un-extended. Will harvest the entire epigeal section of the fruiting and cook down later this week(never cut Sparassis below soil rooting tissue-to insure re fruiting for multiple coming seasons).

Growth Update monitored on 11/13/17. Section where my sample was cut for herbarium/dehydration last week is beginning to “heal over” and fronds are expanding throughout the fruiting body. Constant, heavy rain and colder temps has definitely coaxed the fruiting body to rapid growth and expansion in size. Trichoderma(mold) that I have been monitoring on the sporophore has depleted and is almost non existent(macroscopically) on the base of the FB. Will continue monitoring for another week or two before harvest and possibly a cook out. Images will of course be added for this experience in the near future.

Growth Updated Monitored On 11/9/17-sampled section for herbarium and storage. Dense fronds expanding, nearing full maturity. Trichoderma spp. proliferating the base of fruiting body-deterring from collection for the table this season. Left sclerotium(deep rooting base) of this parasite in tact and undisturbed to return next season/harvest for possible culinary usage.

Growth progress updated: 11/6/17. Trichoderma locations on fruiting body have stalled growth in this sections infected. Areas without mold evident have expanded and are still growing and leafing out. A bit larger than a volleyball at this point. Will continue monitoring until outer petals have lengthened and taken on the “egg noodle” appearance(usually the stage we harvest them). Will hope to have enough material for a small meal(one of our absolute favorite species for the table) and sample small amounts of material for microscopy and herbarium storage.

Updated on 10/31/17: Mold(Trichoderma spp) proliferating the fruiting body. Will continue monitoring to see how the mold infestation affects the progression and growth to maturity.

Growth Progress UPDATED on 10/19/17: Multiple images added of growth 11 days after initial observation. Will continue to monitor until full maturity. Currently the Sporophore is about the size of a volleyball(initial observation was baseball/softball sized). Beginning to unfortunately form Trichoderma flushes at the base and on a few of the extending lobes. Will be fun to see how this works out and if the antibacterial constituents in the Sparassis will over run the blue mold or not. We will see. I anticipate that this will be at full maturity by mid December(depending on frost and precipitation).

The youngest and freshest collection of S. radicata I have been lucky enough to photograph. Approximately the size of a softball. I will continue to monitor this fruiting for at least a month until fully mature(taking images each week to show growth). Parasitizing the base of a second growth Douglas fir.

Elevation: Sea level.

Will collect samples for herbarium at full maturity.

results.notes:
On red clay soil and gravels at edge of grassy meadow and chaparral slope.

Thallus composed of round to somewhat elongate brown, plane, dull squamules up to about 2mm, each with one apothecia deeply immersed, without soredia. Apothecia disk reddish, hymenium hyaline, K/I-, epihymenium yellow-brown and strongly K+R.

Asci broadly clavate with many small round ascospores. Asci K/I+purplish, lightly.

results.notes:
Based on a DNA match for a soil sample Tom Bruns et. al. published in 2004 which is a 100% match for the holotype ITS sequence if Amanita alpinicola, if you ignore a few base pairs at the end of the sequence.

The sequence is GenBank AY702732, “ectomycorrhizal root isolate TK1923B”. It does not list any location, but Dr. Bruns was able to provide it via email.

The elevation of the collection location ranges from 2000 to 2800 meters, and the date is only accurate to within a couple years.
